bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, November 16, [19--]

div1.p: Lambert informs Truby that he has tried to gain recognition as a nurse for the experimental yellow fever cases. He explains the reasons why he thinks he should be included.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, November 16, [19--]
div1.p:
1
Chicago Nov 16th Gen. A E Truby
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY

Andrus have I understand mentioned
to you that I have tried to gain recog-
nition as nurse for the yellow fever
commission I have, and bills have
passed the Senate twice but blocked
in the House by objection from the
War Dept. because others have tried to
be placed on the list, Schwieger was
an orderly an Maj. Carthwright and Dr.
Lezear Cases, he was an immune, had
yellow fever at guanajay he claim
he ought to be on the list having helped
taking care of Dr Lezear: When I disinfected
all bedding from hospital and camp Lezear
Morris helped (detailed to do so) he has tried
to get on the list. Dr Pinto had a bill in
congress trying for recognition for his “heroic
work risking his life in the yellow fever
Hospital.” (I have that congressional record) I
wrote the Hon. Senator Lewis to please let
me tistify against that bill when it was
2
called, it was never put on the callender
I don't know if Mrs Warner has tried
her luck, if she hasn't she has succeeded
in another place (Please see, the clipping) as
soon as I've read the clipping I wrote
Mrs Warner and told her I did not think
it fair for her to receive honors for
work that I did, I asked her to deny in
the same paper that she was the nurse,
althought I inclosed self addressed stamped
envelop she never answered, no doubt
she thought I was dead, as well as all
those connected with the experiment that
knew the truth. In the book "Walter Reed
and yellow fever on page 276 there is a
few lines that every time I read it I get
mad it says that in order to have success
in the treatmen of yellow fever trained
female nurses should be y used; amongst
the five officers Cartwright Patterson Edmunds
Dr. Lezear and Carroll who were sick with
yellow fever, nursed by trained female
immune nurses four of the five died I
nursed over Sixty cases for Dr Ames at
(Military Hosp. no. 1)
No 1. and at quemados, and only one died
3
a sergeant from the battery the man
had been a heavy drinker. I am not
saying that I cured the patient no no, but
whatever Dr Ames said to do, was done,
nothing more and nothing less If Dr Ames
had wanted the patients tapped over the
head ever so often with a baseball batt
it would have been done Only once did I
see Camp Lezear Dr Ames took me with
him in an ambulance but I was not
allowed to step out, the upprights of the
building was up and the Dr told me
what it would be used for I then
asked him to let me be the first
one to sleep there and make $10000.
you have made extra money already he
told me, besides I need you down
below, I did make $9300 extra when I
put up a disinfection plant for
Maj. Gorgas at Las Animas and learned
a man how to use it I later
asked Maj. Reed to let me have a bit &
of the mosquitoes but was told that
Dr Ames needed me. Amongst the men
who took part in the experiment there
4
were four who took the dirty clothing
test only, if yellow fever had been con-
tagious I was more exposed to it
then any one of the four, I handled not
only the clothing but the patients, the
excrement from the patients I helped
Dr Agramonte with the autopsy an
the sergeant who died when the officers
got through in the morgue the left, I
served up the corps cleaned it and
when I was ready to put the body
in the casked I went to the door
and asked for help, the whole battery was
lined up outside but there was not
a man amongst his comrads who
would come in and help me, So
I had to partly roll and partly dump
the corps in to the casket after lid was
on I had to drag casket to door as
they wouldn't even come inside the
Morgue. During the experiment an old man
by the name of Sullivan was picked up
on the street in quemados. The 5th day
he had black vomit twice in the fore-
noon I saved some of the vomit for
5
Dr. Carroll to be used in the labratory
by order of Dr Ames, I'n the afternoon
Maj. Gorgas came in with Dr ames
and while they were talking Dr Ames
called to nu get the pan! The pan being
too far under the bed I had to get down
on my knees to reach it, and while
doing so Sullivan let go and spewed
black vomit over my head and neck
Maj. Gorgas grabbed a towell and threw
over my head and asked if I had any
disinfectant I had a tubb full outside
when they left I heard Sullivan ask
the Major to come in and see him
again, when they got outside Maj Gorgas
said poor fellow, I won't have a chance
to see him again. Three days later the
Major called and asked why the death
we had down there had not been
reported I was answering the phone
and said there hasn't been any death
here. Major asked what about old Sullivan
I answered Sullivan isn't dead he is
sitting up in bed today. I don't know
6
where Maj. Gorgas phone from, but in
less than 20 minutes he was down at
the hospitals I heard him telling Sullivan
that he was the first person he had seen
who at his age. “Sullivan was about 62 or 64”
recovered after having black vomit 3 times
I think if yellow fever could have been
contracted through contagion I was
more exposed to it than the four who
took dirty clothing test I guess that was
why Maj. Reed every time he came down
asked. how do you feel Lambert? In
1930 I had a letter from the War Dept.
saying that only to those essential to
the commission would recognition
be given, surely the commission had
to have someone to care for the men
after they got sick. In 1934 I had another
letter from the War Dept stating that to
the men who took part in the experiment
a small sum of money was given
and that my name was not on the
list of those paid If Dr Ames could have
foreseen that 30 years later those paid
7
would be recognized as the only
onse essential to the commission he
would have chased be accross the rail
road cut so that Maj. Reed could have
asked me to volunteer to take care
of the experimental cases as I had
previously had volunteered to care
for the natural cases I know Maj Reed
would have given me the $100 without
asking if he could have foreseen what
would happen 30 years later. “Please
see Sen Thomas's report” In 1937
the Hon. Costella of Calif voted against my Bill
but on the 14th of May 1940 when I had
an opportunity to appear before the
congressional Committee I proved
even to him that I was the only nurse
Senator Lewis of Illinois pomissed me
before he died that if, or when I should
come to Washington he would see
that I would get an interview
with the Surg Gen and be permited
to prove my claim of having been
the nurse for the yellow fever commission
AC
In to L
I could have done it easy (Sen. Lewis
is now dead) and I lost my chance
General I know I could convince
you if I had only half a chance

Very respectfully yours
Gust. E. Lambert
P. S I am sorry it has taken me so
long to answer but I'm blind on
one eye and the good one is very poor
after writing a litte I have to quit
Lambert
